details.name: DNA methylation
details.description: A chemical modification of DNA where a methyl group is added to the cytosine base, often associated with gene silencing.
details.findings: The article describes specific DNA methylation patterns in CTCs that differ from primary tumors and metastases, suggesting their potential as biomarkers for colorectal cancer.
details.notes: Data obtained using EPIC array is publicly available at the Gene Expression Omnibus (GEO) repository with Accession Number GSE220096.

knowledge.subject: DNA methylation
knowledge.object: CTCs compared to primary tumors and metastases

details.name: glycoprotein NMR signals
details.description: Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) signals from glycoproteins in human serum.
details.findings: The article reassigned the glycoprotein NMR signals from human serum and demonstrated their potential for medical diagnostics of blood samples.
details.notes: NMR is uniquely suitable to identify a range of proteins from one single measurement, it is non-destructive, and yields information on the glycan structures.

details.name: IgG
details.description: Immunoglobulin G, a type of antibody.
details.findings: The article did not explicitly mention IgG but it is implied as part of the glycoprotein signals in human serum.

details.findings: The article did not explicitly mention IgM but it is implied as part of the glycoprotein signals in human serum.

details.name: C-reactive protein (CRP)
details.description: A protein produced by the liver that increases in response to inflammation.
details.findings: The article did not explicitly mention CRP but it is implied as part of the glycoprotein signals in human serum.

details.name: fibrinogen
details.description: A protein involved in blood clotting.
details.findings: The article did not explicitly mention fibrinogen but it is implied as part of the glycoprotein signals in human serum.

details.name: haptoglobin
details.description: A protein that binds free hemoglobin released from red blood cells and transports it to the liver for degradation.
details.findings: The article did not explicitly mention haptoglobin but it is implied as part of the glycoprotein signals in human serum.

details.name: alpha-1-acid glycoprotein (AGP)
details.description: A glycoprotein that binds and transports various substances, including drugs and hormones.
details.findings: The article did not explicitly mention alpha-1-acid glycoprotein but it is implied as part of the glycoprotein signals in human serum.

details.name: transferrin
details.description: A glycoprotein that binds iron and transports it in the blood.
details.findings: The article did not explicitly mention transferrin but it is implied as part of the glycoprotein signals in human serum.

details.name: Nephelometry
details.description: A technique used to measure the concentration of proteins in a solution by detecting light scattering.
details.findings: The article compared NMR with nephelometry, stating that NMR is uniquely suitable for identifying a range of proteins from one single measurement and is not dependent on glycosylation.

knowledge.subject: Nephelometry

details.description: A microRNA that regulates different carcinogenic physiological behaviors and has been reported as a potential biomarker for early diagnosis and prognosis of CRC.
details.findings: miR-126 has shown robust predictive data for early stages of CRC when detected in circulating exosomes (CEx).
details.notes: Part of the CEx-miRNAs panel proposed for minimally invasive methods, such as blood samples (serum).

details.name: MSI-H
details.description: Microsatellite instability-high status indicating a high frequency of mutations in microsatellite sequences.
details.findings: MSI-H confers substantial improvements in clinical outcomes and decreased toxicities through immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICI), offering patients long-term survival or near curative results.
details.notes: MSI-H is a positive predictive biomarker for ICI response in CRC.

knowledge.subject: MSI-H
knowledge.predicate: confers substantial improvements in clinical outcomes and decreased toxicities through

knowledge.subject: MSI-H
knowledge.object: long-term survival or near curative results

details.name: RAS
details.description: Mutations in the RAS gene family, which are involved in cell signaling pathways.
details.findings: The predictive capacity of RAS mutations necessitates a molecular-targeted approach in CRC.
details.notes: RAS mutations are important for targeted therapy selection in CRC.

details.name: BRAF V600E
details.description: Specific mutation in the BRAF gene, which is involved in cell growth and division.
details.findings: BRAF V600E had a negative prognostic value but is now predictive of the response to combined targeted BRAF/EGFR inhibition, doubling survival over standard treatments.
details.notes: BRAF V600E mutation status is crucial for selecting combination therapy in CRC.

knowledge.subject: BRAF V600E

details.name: MHC Class I
details.description: Major histocompatibility complex class I molecules involved in antigen presentation.
details.findings: MHC Class I expression is crucial for the efficacy of immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICI).
details.notes: High MHC Class I expression can enhance the response to ICI therapy.

knowledge.subject: MHC Class I
knowledge.predicate: is crucial for the efficacy of

details.name: HLA
details.description: Human leukocyte antigen system, which is part of the immune system and involved in antigen presentation.
details.findings: HLA expression levels can influence the response to immunotherapy.
details.notes: HLA typing may be useful for predicting ICI response.

knowledge.subject: HLA
knowledge.predicate: expression levels can influence the response to

details.name: PD-L1
details.description: Programmed death-ligand 1, which is involved in suppressing the immune system.
details.findings: PD-L1 expression can be a predictive biomarker for response to immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICI).
details.notes: High PD-L1 expression may indicate better response to ICI therapy.

knowledge.subject: PD-L1
knowledge.predicate: expression can be a predictive biomarker for response to

details.name: TMB
details.description: Tumor mutational burden, which is the total number of mutations present in a tumor.
details.findings: High TMB can predict response to immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICI).
details.notes: TMB is being evaluated as a biomarker for ICI therapy.

details.name: KRAS
details.description: Mutations in the KRAS gene, which are involved in cell signaling pathways.
details.findings: KRAS mutations can influence response to targeted therapies and immunotherapy.
details.notes: KRAS mutation status is important for treatment selection in CRC.

details.name: FAP-α
details.description: Fibroblast activation protein alpha, which is expressed by cancer-associated fibroblasts.
details.findings: FAP-α expression can be a marker for the presence of stromal cells in tumors and may influence response to therapy.
details.notes: FAP-α is being studied as a potential biomarker for targeted therapies.

knowledge.subject: FAP-α
knowledge.predicate: expression can be a marker for the presence of stromal cells in tumors and may influence response to

details.name: Casapse-3
details.description: A key executioner of apoptosis (programmed cell death).
details.findings: The article does not explicitly mention findings related to caspase-3, but it is likely involved in the assessment of cell viability and response to treatment.
details.notes: Not directly mentioned in the article, but typically used as a biomarker for apoptosis.

details.name: Ki67
details.description: A marker of cell proliferation.
details.findings: The article does not explicitly mention findings related to Ki67, but it is likely used to assess the proliferative activity of cells.
details.notes: Not directly mentioned in the article, but typically used as a biomarker for cell proliferation.

details.name: Caspase-8
details.description: A key initiator of apoptosis.
details.findings: The article does not explicitly mention findings related to caspase-8, but it is likely involved in the assessment of cell viability and response to treatment.
details.notes: Not directly mentioned in the article, but typically used as a biomarker for early stages of apoptosis.

details.name: Bcl-2
details.description: An anti-apoptotic protein that inhibits cell death.
details.findings: The article does not explicitly mention findings related to Bcl-2, but it is likely used to assess the balance between pro- and anti-apoptotic signals in cells.
details.notes: Not directly mentioned in the article, but typically used as a biomarker for apoptosis regulation.

details.name: Caspase-9
details.description: A key mediator of the intrinsic apoptotic pathway.
details.findings: The article does not explicitly mention findings related to caspase-9, but it is likely involved in the assessment of cell viability and response to treatment.
details.notes: Not directly mentioned in the article, but typically used as a biomarker for intrinsic apoptosis.

details.name: p53
details.description: A tumor suppressor protein that regulates cell cycle and induces apoptosis.
details.findings: The article does not explicitly mention findings related to p53, but it is likely used to assess the response to DNA damage and cell stress.
details.notes: Not directly mentioned in the article, but typically used as a biomarker for cellular stress and tumor suppression.

details.name: VEGF
details.description: A growth factor that promotes angiogenesis and tumor progression.
details.findings: The article does not explicitly mention findings related to VEGF, but it is likely used to assess the angiogenic activity of tumors.
details.notes: Not directly mentioned in the article, but typically used as a biomarker for angiogenesis.

details.name: guanylate cyclase-C (GUCY2C)
details.description: A membrane-bound receptor that mediates the effects of guanylin and uroguanylin, which are involved in intestinal homeostasis.
details.findings: Guanylate cyclase-C was used as a target for chimeric antigen receptor T-cell therapy in patients with colorectal cancer.
details.notes: This biomarker is highly expressed in colorectal cancer cells and was the target for the CAR-T therapy described in the article.

knowledge.subject: guanylate cyclase-C (GUCY2C)
knowledge.predicate: was used as a target for

details.name: hCRISPRs
details.description: Human CRISPR-like sequences found in the human genome.
details.findings: hCRISPRs are detected and validated as potential biomarkers for transcriptional regulation and diagnostics.
details.notes: These sequences show homology to bacterial CRISPR systems and may have functional roles in human cells.

knowledge.subject: hCRISPRs
knowledge.object: potential biomarkers for transcriptional regulation and diagnostics

details.name: acetone
details.description: A chemical with an abnormal fruity odor that may be considered as a cancer biomarker but can also change due to physical activities and fasting.
details.findings: Acetone concentration in breath changes during activities such as exercising or fasting, limiting its use as a reliable cancer biomarker.
details.notes: Exogenous factors like physical activity and smoking can affect acetone levels.

knowledge.subject: acetone
knowledge.object: during activities such as exercising or fasting

details.name: 4-heptanone
details.description: A volatile organic compound whose origin is unclear and thus not recommended for use as a cancer biomarker.
details.findings: The origins of 4-heptanone are unclear, limiting its use as a reliable cancer biomarker.
details.notes: Further research on the origins of 4-heptanone is needed.

knowledge.subject: 4-heptanone
knowledge.predicate: is not recommended for use as

details.name: acetone (as a cancer biomarker)
details.description: A chemical with an abnormal fruity odor that has been considered as a potential cancer biomarker.
details.findings: Acetone is considered an adequate cancer biomarker but its concentration in breath changes due to exogenous factors, limiting its reliability.
details.notes: Exogenous factors like physical activity and smoking can affect acetone levels.

details.name: Bacteroides fragilis
details.description: A gram-negative anaerobic bacterium commonly found in the human gut.
details.findings: Bacteroides fragilis was identified as a significant biomarker for distinguishing between healthy and CRC patients.
details.notes: Found to be more abundant in CRC patients.

details.name: Fusobacterium nucleatum
details.description: A gram-negative anaerobic bacterium associated with periodontal disease and colorectal cancer.
details.findings: Fusobacterium nucleatum was found to be significantly more abundant in CRC patients compared to healthy individuals.
details.notes: Strongly correlated with CRC presence.

details.name: Alistipes putredinis
details.description: A gram-negative anaerobic bacterium found in the human gut.
details.findings: Alistipes putredinis was identified as a biomarker with increased abundance in CRC patients.
details.notes: Increased presence may indicate higher risk of CRC.

details.name: Faecalibacterium prausnitzii
details.description: A gram-positive anaerobic bacterium known for its anti-inflammatory properties.
details.findings: Faecalibacterium prausnitzii was found to be less abundant in CRC patients compared to healthy individuals.
details.notes: Decreased presence may indicate a protective role against CRC.

details.name: Acetone
details.description: A ketone related to lipid peroxidation and a good predictor for ketosis.
details.findings: Acetone levels were higher in the exhaled breath of CRC patients compared to controls.

details.name: Alcohols
details.description: Derived from food, alcohol beverages, and metabolism of hydrocarbons by cytochrome p450 enzymes.
details.findings: The levels of alcohols were different in the exhaled breath of CRC patients compared to controls.

details.name: Hydrocarbons
details.description: Excreted in the breath due to low solubility in blood and affected by oxidative stress.
details.findings: The levels of hydrocarbons were different in the exhaled breath of CRC patients compared to controls.

details.name: Esters
details.description: Found in natural sources such as fats, fatty oils, waxes, and fruit ethers.
details.findings: The levels of esters were different in the exhaled breath of CRC patients compared to controls.

details.name: Alkenes
details.description: Potentially involved in oxidative stress and the emission of hydrocarbons.
details.findings: The levels of alkenes were different in the exhaled breath of CRC patients compared to controls.

details.name: Ketones
details.description: Secondary products of lipid peroxidation and related to acetone.
details.findings: The levels of ketones were different in the exhaled breath of CRC patients compared to controls.

details.name: T-antigen
details.description: An immature glycan associated with cancer and other diseases, characterized by a core structure of Galβ1-3GalNAc.
details.findings: Stools from more aggressive lesions exhibit abnormal T-antigen signatures not seen in healthy tissues.
details.notes: T-antigen is a potential biomarker for non-invasive CRC screening.

details.name: PNA-enriched glycoproteins
details.description: Glycoproteins enriched by PNA, which bind to T-antigen and other related glycans.
details.findings: Several molecular targets shared by more aggressive non-cancerous lesions and cancer were identified in the stool glycoproteome.
details.notes: These glycoproteins hold promise for future pre-clinical assessment.

knowledge.subject: PNA-enriched glycoproteins
knowledge.object: more aggressive non-cancerous lesions and cancer

qwen2.5:72b/PPEkf.prompt_template:
[BEGIN ARTICLE]:<content></content>
[END ARTICLE]

[INSTRUCTIONS]
Generate list of biomarkers that are topic of the article and for each such biomarker extract name, description, type, findings explicitly mentioned in the article, and list of knowledge.
The list of knowledge that are from finding and that can be expressed in terms: 'subject' which is the biomarker, 'predicate' which is some verb optionally with some adverb and 'object'.
Return the response in strict JSON format with the following structure:

[
  { "name": "biomarker name","type":"biomarker type","description":"biomarker description","findings":"brief findings about biomarker in article as one sentence","notes":"additional notes important to biomarker", "knowledge":[{'subject':'repeated biomarker name','predicate':'some predicate from findings of biomarker','object':'object that relates via predicate to the biomarker' }],
  { "name": "biomarker2 name","type":"biomarker2 type","description":"biomarker2 description","findings":"brief findings about biomarker2 in article as one sentence","notes":"additional notes important to biomarker2", "knowledge":[{'subject':'repeated biomarker2 name','predicate':'some predicate from findings of  biomarker2','object':'object that relates via predicate to the biomarker2' }] }
] 

Ensure there is no additional explanation, only return valid JSON.
